articles.headline: China's Economy Continues to Race Ahead
articles.snippet: China's economy continues to race ahead in April despite series of measures by government to slow growth; volume of bank loans is up 20.4 percent from year earlier, little changed from year-over-year increase of 20.7 percent in March; money supply...
articles.abstract: China's economy continues to race ahead in April despite series of measures by government to slow growth; volume of bank loans is up 20.4 percent from year earlier, little changed from year-over-year increase of 20.7 percent in March; money supply is up 19.1 percent in April, same as March; industrial production rises 19.1 percent from year earlier, compared with 19.4 percent in March; foreign direct investment accelerates, climbing 10.1 percent for first four months of year compared with period last year; contracts for future foreign direct investment rise 54 percent for first four months of year; imports rise 43 percent in April compared with year ago while exports climb 32 percent; faster growth of imports produces trade deficit of $2.3 billion; graph; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: China's economy continued to barrel ahead in April despite a series of measures by Beijing to slow growth, a raft of statistics showed on Thursday.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Profit Rises
articles.snippet: ING says first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, to 1.2 billion euros ($1.4 billion); income at ING's banking operations rose 13 percent, to 3.3 billion euros; graph (S)
articles.abstract: ING says first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, to 1.2 billion euros ($1.4 billion); income at ING's banking operations rose 13 percent, to 3.3 billion euros; graph (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: The insurance and banking concern ING said that its first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, to 1.2 billion euros ($1.4 billion), helped by its strong life insurance business in the United States and its Internet banking division, ING Direct. ING earned 902 million euros a year earlier. Income at ING's banking operations rose 13 percent, to 3.3 billion euros.

articles.headline: PREMIER OF INDIA IS FORCED TO QUIT AFTER VOTE UPSET
articles.snippet: Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India resigns after his governing coalition suffers shocking upset in parliamentary elections; his Hindu nationalist party has led India since 1998; peace process with Pakistan that has advanced on trust built bet...
articles.abstract: Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India resigns after his governing coalition suffers shocking upset in parliamentary elections; his Hindu nationalist party has led India since 1998; peace process with Pakistan that has advanced on trust built between him and Gen Pervez Musharraf could be affected; electoral defeat, which was not forecast by any major poll or pundit, is seen as repudiation of Vajpayee's agenda of privatization and other economic reforms; his message that an ascendant India was banishing poverty was mockery to struggling farmers and legions of unemployed; Indian National Congress led by Sonia Gandhi capitalized on widespread discontent to emerge as single largest party; party appears poised to form country's next government with support of electoral allies and country's Communist parties; Gandhi seems likely to claim prime minister's post, although fact that she was not born in India might stand in way; she is widow of former Prime Min Rajiv Gandhi; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, whose Hindu nationalist party had led India since 1998, resigned Thursday after his governing coalition suffered a shocking upset in parliamentary elections.

articles.headline: AT IRAQI PRISON, RUMSFELD VOWS TO PUNISH ABUSE
articles.snippet: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld visits Abu Ghraib prison, pledging that world will see America mete out punishment openly and freely to any soldier guilty of abuse; his whirlwind visit to prison is not announced until his arrival in Baghdad; he does...
articles.abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld visits Abu Ghraib prison, pledging that world will see America mete out punishment openly and freely to any soldier guilty of abuse; his whirlwind visit to prison is not announced until his arrival in Baghdad; he does not speak with any detainees, but holds meetings with prison commanders and large gathering of military police who replaced those serving during time of abuses; he claims acts of violence or humiliation do not 'represent America' and were carried out by tiny fraction of United States Military in Iraq; Maj Gen Geoffrey Miller, new deputy commanding general for detention operations in Iraq, says all prisoners under American control will be moved out of old Abu Ghraib structures and into new facilities within Abu Ghraib compound; says old prison blocks will be solely for criminals incarcerated by new Iraqi government; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, entering the heart of the global furor over the mistreatment of Iraqi detainees, walked inside the faded yellow walls and razor wire of Abu Ghraib prison on Thursday to pledge that the world will see America mete out punishment openly and freely to any soldier guilty of abuse.

articles.headline: Senators Assail Request for Aid For the Military
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats and Republicans attack Bush administration officials for submitting vaguely worded request to add $25 billion to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan beginning Oct 1; say request lacks specific details and seeks to circumven...
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats and Republicans attack Bush administration officials for submitting vaguely worded request to add $25 billion to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan beginning Oct 1; say request lacks specific details and seeks to circumvent Senate's oversight role; Sen John McCain calls it 'blank check'; new money is in addition to $400 billion already sought for military uses worldwide in fiscal 2005; Sen Robert C Byrd predicts that Senate will approve extra money to pay for fuel, body armor, troop transportation and supplies, but with some strings attached; during contentious three-hour hearing, Democratic Sen Jack Reed accuses Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz of botching his job and Sen Edward M Kennedy objects to Sen John W Warner's effort to limit scope of questions to budget request; some lawmakers say some interrogation methods used in Iraq violate Geneva Conventions; Wolfowitz and Gen Peter Pace acknowledge that taken individually some of approved techniques could be interpreted as violating conventions; double-barreled jousting over two sensitive parts of Iraq policy, cost and treatment of prisoners, underscores growing unrest on Capital Hill over operations there; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats and Republicans attacked Bush administration officials on Thursday for submitting a vaguely worded request to add $25 billion to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan beginning on Oct. 1.

articles.headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
articles.snippet: As Profit Rises, Wal-Mart Offers Note of Caution  Wal-Mart Stores reported that its profits for the first quarter rose 16 percent and that overall sales, bolstered by growing interest in apparel, increased at the fastest pace in more than two year...
articles.abstract: As Profit Rises, Wal-Mart Offers Note of Caution  Wal-Mart Stores reported that its profits for the first quarter rose 16 percent and that overall sales, bolstered by growing interest in apparel, increased at the fastest pace in more than two years.    But H. Lee Scott, the company's chief executive, warned that soaring gasoline prices could put a crimp in consumer spending in the months ahead, potentially slowing the gains the world's largest retailer previously forecast. [Page C3.]
articles.lead_paragraph: As Profit Rises, Wal-Mart Offers Note of Caution

articles.headline: As Prices Rise, Russia Alters Oil Politics Toward U.S.
articles.snippet: Government officials and foreign and Russian energy companies say once-promising US-Russia energy dialogue is sputtering; Russian government no longer feels compelled to sell oil to America with global oil prices soaring and Russian producers raki...
articles.abstract: Government officials and foreign and Russian energy companies say once-promising US-Russia energy dialogue is sputtering; Russian government no longer feels compelled to sell oil to America with global oil prices soaring and Russian producers raking in profits; hope-for pipeline from Caspian Sea to Murmansk in far northern Russia, from which Russian oil companies could ship to US, will probably not be built; Russian government is negotiating to build pipeline to Nakhodka, port of Sea of Japan, which will bring oil to East Asia; project has $6 billion in financing promised from Japanese government; war in Iraq has soured relations between US and Russia, which sided with France and Germany in opposing conflict; arrest of Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, billionaire oil tycoon and founder of Yukos, was final blow; Khodorkovsky pushed for higher oil exports to West before he was jailed; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost three years after the Sept. 11 attacks, America is still seeking sources of energy besides the Middle East, and Russia has plenty of oil to sell.

articles.headline: Home Depot to Double Its Size In Mexico After Buying Rival
articles.snippet: Home Depot Inc will acquire Mexican home improvement retailer Home Mart Mexico, doubling its presence in Mexico, country experiencing home-building boom; Home Depot will have 39 stores in central and northern Mexico, all under Home Depot brand, on...
articles.abstract: Home Depot Inc will acquire Mexican home improvement retailer Home Mart Mexico, doubling its presence in Mexico, country experiencing home-building boom; Home Depot will have 39 stores in central and northern Mexico, all under Home Depot brand, once acquisition is completed; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Home Depot Inc. said Thursday that it would acquire the Mexican home improvement retailer Home Mart México, doubling its presence in Mexico as the country experiences a homebuilding boom.

articles.headline: Fears Drain Support for Natural Gas Terminals
articles.snippet: Growing outcry over environmental and safety risks associated with natural gas terminals is blocking plans in many communities to build terminals, eroding hopes that imports of liquefied gas will provide any relief from high gas prices for years t...
articles.abstract: Growing outcry over environmental and safety risks associated with natural gas terminals is blocking plans in many communities to build terminals, eroding hopes that imports of liquefied gas will provide any relief from high gas prices for years to come; opposition has been most pronounced in California, New England and northwestern Mexico; problems that companies have had in gaining approval for terminals, which can cost from $500 million to $1 billion and take three to five years to build, come at critical time for rapidly growing sector of energy industry; companies that have canceled gas projects because of intense local opposition include Calpine Corp, ConocoPhillips, Marathon Oil and Exxon Mobil; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Regulators Fine Riggs $25 Million
articles.snippet: Federal regulators fine Riggs National Corp, parent of Riggs Bank, $25 million for failing to report suspicious activity; fine, largest ever assessed against domestic bank in connection with money laundering, stems from Rigg's failure over at leas...
articles.abstract: Federal regulators fine Riggs National Corp, parent of Riggs Bank, $25 million for failing to report suspicious activity; fine, largest ever assessed against domestic bank in connection with money laundering, stems from Rigg's failure over at least last two years to actively monitor suspect financial transfers through Saudi Arabian and Equatorial Guinean accounts held by bank; accounts are still being scrutinized as possible conduits for terrorist funds or for proceeds of graft; Saudi Arabian Embassy spokesman denies any involvement by Saudi officials in terrorist financing activities through Riggs; Equatorial Guinean Embassy does not return calls seeking comment; Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, investigative arm of Treasury Department, and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, regulatory arm of same agency, each impose $25 million penalties against Riggs, but bank will be allowed to pay them concurrently (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators fined the Riggs National Corporation, the parent company of Riggs Bank, $25 million yesterday for failing to report suspicious activity, the largest penalty ever assessed against a domestic bank in connection with money laundering.

articles.headline: Accused Soldier Paints Scene of Eager Mayhem
articles.snippet: Specialist Jeremy C Sivits portrays night of gratuitous and random violence at Abu Ghraib prison in his statements to investigators; he descibes scene of twisted joviality not authorized by anyone in chain of command and with no connection to any ...
articles.abstract: Specialist Jeremy C Sivits portrays night of gratuitous and random violence at Abu Ghraib prison in his statements to investigators; he descibes scene of twisted joviality not authorized by anyone in chain of command and with no connection to any interrogations; lawyers for other soldiers charged have said they were operating on orders of military intelligence in effort to get detainees to talk; Sivits is first to be court-martialed, and is expected to plead guilty and testify against others; he says soldiers knew what they did was wrong, even instructing him not to tell anyone what he had seen (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: When a fresh crop of detainees arrived at Abu Ghraib prison one night in late October, their jailers set upon them.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Posts Gain
articles.snippet: French bank Societe Generale says profit rose 65.8 percent, to 801 million euros ($953.4 million), in first quarter (S)
articles.abstract: French bank Societe Generale says profit rose 65.8 percent, to 801 million euros ($953.4 million), in first quarter (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: The French bank Société Générale said profit rose 65.8 percent, to 801 million euros ($953.4 million), in the first quarter, helped by strong results in its core businesses, low provisions for bad loans, and capital gains. The bank's corporate and investment banking division reported its best performance since the first quarter of 2000 with income of 329 million euros, up 66.2 percent from the year-earlier period. Société Générale said it earned 127 million euros from the sale of its stake in the property company Sophia and set aside 48 million euros for bad loans, down from a quarterly average of 130 million euros in 2003. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
articles.snippet: Orders for new machinery in Japan fall 3.2 percent in March from February, tempering some of recent optimism about strength of Japan's economic recovery; government still expects orders to rise over long term (S)
articles.abstract: Orders for new machinery in Japan fall 3.2 percent in March from February, tempering some of recent optimism about strength of Japan's economic recovery; government still expects orders to rise over long term (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Orders for new machinery fell 3.2 percent in March from February, tempering some of the recent optimism about the strength of Japan's economic recovery. The decline was unexpected, as economists were forecasting a moderate increase in the figure, an important though sometimes volatile statistic. The drop was partly a result of weakness in orders from telecommunications companies and other nonmanufacturers. The government still expects orders to rise over the long term, an official said.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda's Profit Rises
articles.snippet: Mazda Motor Corp says net profit rose 40.5 percent, to 33.9 billion yen ($299.8 million), for year ended March 31; revenue rose 23 percent, to 2.92 trillion yen (S)
articles.abstract: Mazda Motor Corp says net profit rose 40.5 percent, to 33.9 billion yen ($299.8 million), for year ended March 31; revenue rose 23 percent, to 2.92 trillion yen (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Mazda Motor Corporation said its net profit rose 40.5 percent, to 33.9 billion yen ($299.8 million), for the year ended March 31, helped by strong sales of the Axela sedan and other new models in Europe. Mazda posted a 23 percent increase in revenue for the year, to 2.92 trillion yen. The strong performance comes after years of restructuring under the guidance of Ford, which owns a third of Mazda and is using Mazda technology in many of its newest cars. However, Mazda forecast profit would remain about the same for the year ahead. Todd Zaun (NYT)

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Profit Slips
articles.snippet: Deutsche Telekom earned 169 million euros ($201 million) in first quarter as sales increased 3 percent, to 14 billion euros (S)
articles.abstract: Deutsche Telekom earned 169 million euros ($201 million) in first quarter as sales increased 3 percent, to 14 billion euros (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Telekom said it earned 169 million euros ($201 million) in the first quarter, short of market forecasts, as sales increased 3 percent, to 14 billion euros. The chief executive, Kai-Uwe Ricke, said the weak German economy hurt results and sales at its German fixed-line operation, its biggest unit, fell 6 percent. Income was also hurt by expenses for a venture with DaimlerChrysler that is developing a system that will use satellites to charge truck tolls on German highways. Petra Kappl (NYT)

articles.headline: German Bank Deal Off, Despite Government Effort
articles.snippet: Deutsche Post, mail and delivery giant that owns Postbank, plans to move ahead with bank's previously announced stock offering in June, rejecting sale to Deutsche Bank and pledging to hold on to majority stake in newly public company; is setback f...
articles.abstract: Deutsche Post, mail and delivery giant that owns Postbank, plans to move ahead with bank's previously announced stock offering in June, rejecting sale to Deutsche Bank and pledging to hold on to majority stake in newly public company; is setback for German officials, who had hoped that deal would kick off consolidation in banking; Postbank episode is being regarded in Germany as watershed--sign that Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has decided to emulate French policy of creating and supporting national industrial champions; failure to bring off deal illustrates difficulties Germans face in attempting to follow France's policy; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The short, obviously strained mating dance between Deutsche Bank and Germany's largest retail bank, Postbank, appeared to fizzle on Thursday, but not before raising questions about the German government meddling in industry.

articles.headline: Pfizer to Pay $430 Million Over Promoting Drug to Doctors
articles.snippet: Pfizer pleads guilty and agrees to pay $430 million to resolve criminal and civil charges that it paid doctors to prescribe epilepsy drug Neurontin to patients with ailments that drug was not federally approved to treat; Dr David P Franklin, medic...
articles.abstract: Pfizer pleads guilty and agrees to pay $430 million to resolve criminal and civil charges that it paid doctors to prescribe epilepsy drug Neurontin to patients with ailments that drug was not federally approved to treat; Dr David P Franklin, medical adviser to Warner-Lambert, which Pfizer acquired, will receive $26.64 million of settlement for bringing lawsuit under federal 'whistle-blower' law; doctors are free to prescribe any federally approved drug for whatever use they use, but pharmaceutical companies are not allowed to promote drugs for nonapproved purposes; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Vanity Fair Editor Got $100,000 for Suggesting a Movie
articles.snippet: Graydon Carter, editor in chief of Vanity Fair, received $100,000 payment from Universal Studios in 2003 for suggesting years earlier that book A Beautiful Mind be made into film; film was produced by Image Entertainment, whose principals, Brian G...
articles.abstract: Graydon Carter, editor in chief of Vanity Fair, received $100,000 payment from Universal Studios in 2003 for suggesting years earlier that book A Beautiful Mind be made into film; film was produced by Image Entertainment, whose principals, Brian Grazer and Ron Howard, have made Vanity Fair's annual list of new establishment power brokers last two years, and whose other projects have received attention coverage in magazines; payment of consulting fees to magazine editor who controls coverage of film industry subjects has no precedent; Cynthia Gorney, associate dean of Graduate School of Journalism at University of California, Berkeley, says there is something particularly distressing about nice round figure of $100,000 and fact that it directly lined Carter's pocket (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Graydon Carter, editor in chief of Vanity Fair, received a $100,000 payment from Universal Studios in 2003 for suggesting years earlier that the book ''A Beautiful Mind'' be made into a film, executives involved with the film said. The payment was confirmed by a spokeswoman for the magazine.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Sharon Waxman

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Posts Loss
articles.snippet: Alitalia posts first-quarter loss and says it needs loan from government to survive; will develop revamping plan in next three to four months that will include spinning off company's ground operations (S)
articles.abstract: Alitalia posts first-quarter loss and says it needs loan from government to survive; will develop revamping plan in next three to four months that will include spinning off company's ground operations (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Italian airline Alitalia posted a first-quarter loss and said it needed a loan from the government to survive. It also said it would develop a revamping plan in the next three to four months that would include spinning off the company's ground operations. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Optimistic Outlook
articles.snippet: US Treasury Under Sec John B Taylor says Japan's two-year recovery appears to be on solid ground as result of government efforts to tackle some of worst of country's economic problems; praises Japan's progress in dealing with deflation and bad ban...
articles.abstract: US Treasury Under Sec John B Taylor says Japan's two-year recovery appears to be on solid ground as result of government efforts to tackle some of worst of country's economic problems; praises Japan's progress in dealing with deflation and bad bank loans; photo (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Japan's two-year recovery appears to be on solid ground as a result of government efforts to tackle some of the worst of the country's economic troubles, according to John B. Taylor, left, the under secretary for international affairs in the United States Treasury Department. ''We learned a lot about what we think is a more sustainable recovery than has existed for a long time in Japan,'' Mr. Taylor said after meeting government officials and economists in Tokyo on Thursday. He praised Japan's progress in dealing with deflation and bad bank loans. Mr. Taylor said he was optimistic that Japan's recovery would continue because of recent indications that consumer demand is picking up. Todd Zaun (NYT)

articles.headline: First Insiders Sold Their Shares Privately, Then Salesforce.com Filed to Go Public
articles.snippet: Floyd Norris column urges SEC to change rules that will allow Salesforce.com to go public without telling investors about private sales of stock by insiders; says chief executive Marc Benioff has not said what he did with shares he once owned beca...
articles.abstract: Floyd Norris column urges SEC to change rules that will allow Salesforce.com to go public without telling investors about private sales of stock by insiders; says chief executive Marc Benioff has not said what he did with shares he once owned because SEC rules bar him from talking; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: THE right of investors to know when corporate insiders sell stock -- and at what price -- is a fundamental part of American securities law. When it turned out that Ken Lay, the former chairman of Enron, was using a loophole to sell shares secretly while he urged others to buy, Congress quickly changed the law.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Head Of Tax Agency Named
articles.snippet: David Varney, departing chairman of mobile phone company MM02, is named head of Britain's Inland Revenue and Customs and Excise agencies; two tax agencies are being marged as part of Labor government cost-cutting plan; departments will lay off est...
articles.abstract: David Varney, departing chairman of mobile phone company MM02, is named head of Britain's Inland Revenue and Customs and Excise agencies; two tax agencies are being marged as part of Labor government cost-cutting plan; departments will lay off estimated 10,000 workers (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: David Varney, the departing chairman of the mobile phone company MM02, was named the head of the Inland Revenue and Customs and Excise agencies. The two tax agencies are being merged as part of a Labor government cost-cutting plan. One of his first duties will be to combine information technology departments, and lay off an estimated 10,000 people. Mr. Varney, who worked nearly 30 years at Royal Dutch/Shell, starts at the new post in September. Heather Timmons (NYT)
